The City of Salem is considering as
the initial effort of a proposed urban
renewal project the purchase and razing
of an eight-block area around the WillaWillamette
mette University campus. Under the proprogram,
gram, land would be purchased from its
owners or acquired at condemnation proproceedings.
ments would be leveled and the land
would be resold to the University at bare
The land affected lies generally bebetween
tween 12 th Street and the alley east of
Winter Street S.E., and the Southern PaPacific
cific Trade Street spur and Shelton
Ditch. It would be used as an extension
of the university campus, which has been
described to the Salem City Council by
It is hoped that in the fall issue of the

renewal project affecting the future of
The striking new uniforms worn by
been designed for multiple use and maximaximum
mum effectiveness. The black and white
uniform as shown here worn by Ray
Krueger, student assistant in the band
department, is enlivened by gold braid
trim, scarlet and gold emblem, white
leggings and bright red cockade plume
in the cap. The uniform is worn in this
fashion when the band performs as a
marching unit, but for concerts, the legleggings,
gings, plume and white front overlay are
removed, and the uniform looks much
like a tuxedo. The university is justly
proud of the splendid appearance and fine
. . . And the largest turnout of alums

The following excerpts from the Commencement Address by Tyrone Gillespie are
herewith presented in answer to the many requests from those 2vho were unable
This is the year of Our Lord 1961.
This day of this year is a day set aside
to honor our graduating Seniors, and I
am confident that this day and this year
will be abidingly cherished in the memmemories
ories of our graduates, their parents, and
Will you forgive me, Seniors, if I
address my remarks for a moment to the
faculty? The words that I would direct
to them I know are in your hearts, but
at this moment they are difficult for
Honored Faculty, yours is a noble
profession. Cicero extolled as the noblest
employment of man the instruction of
the rising generation. The greatest man
that ever lived was a teacher. You can
tender for the devotion, the service, the
dedication, the selflessness and the friendfriendship
ship which you have laid upon the altar,
has been small. But you can accept with
assurance that your learning and sacrisacrifice
fice have created an influence for good
which has moved horizontally to the far
corners of the earth and will extend
born. Many of you have built a rich
memorial in the hearts of your students
more to be prized than jewels or gold or
statucs of bronze or stone. For this gradgraduating
uating class and for the classes of the
past who have partaken of your wisdom,
I express a profound thanks and an abidabiding
ing gratefulness too full for adequate
Parents, I would be advocate for this
Senior Class to express a sentiment to
you. Dr. William Moran, President of
marked, upon occasion of a CommenceCommencement
listens to a Commencement address exexcept
cept perhaps a few parents engaged in
one last effort to get something for
their money." You know, and I know,
and he knew that this remark was fafacetious,
cetious, for today you are witnessing the
culmination of many hours of hope, love,
devotion, perhaps some anxiety and in
come cases, sacrifice. The pride you now
feel is your reward, but deep in the hearts
of these fine young men and women lies
an unexpressed obligation to you for the
part you have played in making today
become a reality. This feeling may not be
verbalized but it is present, poignant,
and abiding. Admixed with the emotions
of this day are sentiments of gratitude
It is obvious that the pace and momomentum
man's discovery of the wheel and the
invention of the steam engine. It was 140
years from the invention of the steam
engine to the development of the airairplane.
plane. It was 40 years from the airplane
to the atom bomb. It was only 12 years
from the atom bomb to Sputnik. This
year, only four years from Sputnik, the
first man was launched into space.
This suggests that the world in which
you are to live and achieve will be a very
different world, and soon. Its limitations
are only the limitations of the imaginaimagination
tion of the most fertile mind. We can
with money and effort today approxiapproximate
mate almost anything we can dream. I
dream of a flying carpet and this may
not be a reality, you even now can ride
a flying saucer or a flying bathtub.
Ninety percent of all the scientists
who ever lived are alive today.
At the turn of the century the average
work week was 60 hours in length. Since
that date the work week has shortened
in manufacturing industries at a steady
rate. In the years 1900 to 1930 the work
week dropped from 60 to 50 hours. In
the years 1930 to 1950 it dropped from
5 0 to 40 hours. In the meantime, producproductivity
tivity rose, and is still rising, at about
an average of 2.4 per cent per year.
This indicates that in all likelihood
during your working years in fact in
the next 2 0 years the standard work
Are we prepared for the amount of
leisure we will enjoy? Will the amount
of leisure time cause a restlessness in our
people which will be reflected in inincreased
has been an experience of the past. There
is an Arabian proverb which says, "An
idle person is the devil's playfellow."
Rooted in the long past is an urge to
construct, to create, and a need to invest
one's self in work. In times of unemunemployment
ployment or idleness, the ratio of crime
There is an antidote, there is an ananswer
swer to this problem. Whether you know
it or not, you have found it here at
soever loses his life for my sake shall
save it." You have found in this place
some cause, some creed, some worthwhile
goal in which you can lose yourself,
which will provide you with that obobjective
jective passion which will bring maturity
and the ability to live outside yourself
and for the good of mankind.
Along with a prodigality of leisure,
there travels a dangerous partner: the
evil of materialism. This is evidenced in
too many universities which teach how
to make a living, but not how to live.
It is evidenced in a society which will
independence for security. It is evidenced
in a worship for science without moralmorality.
ity. A nuclear blast has no moral sense
to restrain it from evil or direct it for
good if the hand that controls it has no
calization of an increasing portion of our
lives is destructive of that needed sense
It is with gratification we note that
many modern youths are rebelling against
the hypocrisy of compulsive and degraddegrading
ing political subsidy and are seeking the
proach for solving the needs of their
personal lives, and the selective compascompassionate
sionate approach to assistance to their
fellow man. They are assured by instinct
that only in this way will that psychic
hunger which cannot be satitsfied with
They are seeking a dominant faith to
which to attach their philosophy of life.
Have you had opportunity to hear a
speech contest lately where young people
have their choice of subject matter? You
will be amazed at the number who speak
on religious and spiritual subjects in a
ment of these instincts toward indepenindependence,
the closing of the gap between our philophilosophical
future, to the betterment of both.
You, and each of you, are technotechnologically
logically greater than any machine ever
made, and you will adapt and adjust

If the company you work for is included, be sure to

The "matching gift" idea is as simple as 224. When
you make a contribution, you fill in a short form proprovided

The principal source of funds to improve the program of Willamette is in the category
of gifts and grants. It is the principal source because it is the one area that is "expand"expand-abler
abler since income from investments depends primarily on endowment gifts already
made. Never underestimate the role of your annual gift - whatever its size, it is imporimportant
tant in itself and encourages the gifts of others. It is, truly, an Enriching Tradition.

Foundation, he travels in the ten southsouthwestern

Mrs. HELEN MINTER PETERSON, her hushusband

The first copy of a revised edition of
Dr. Morton E. Peck's "Manual of the
Higher Plants of Oregon" came off the
press in time for the Willamette comcommencement.
mencement. It was a propitious time, because Mrs.
Jessie J. Peck, the widow and for many
years the scientific collaborator of WilWillamette's
lamette's noted botanist, was able to
exhibit the volume at a tea she gave at
her home for almost thirty members of
of this class for a good many years have
made an annual contribution to the Peck
Dr. Peck's manual was published origoriginally
inally in 1941 by Binfords-Mort of PortPortland.
land. Almost immediately Dr. Peck started
the enormous task of revision a task
which held him enthralled during his
twilight years when many another would
have sought only rest and relaxation
after a productive life. Completion of this
in vigorous health. For Professor Peck,
who was known and loved for his quiet
gentleness, it was an incredible triumph
over devastating illness and infirmity. He
literally seemed to be holding death at
bay until he could write "Finis" to his
to a distinguished career as Oregon's
outstanding botanist and as a beloved
member of the faculty of Willamette
In all this labor, Dr. Peck received and
assistance given by his wife. During his
lifetime, they were a joyous team, exexploring
ploring the hills and fields of Oregon
in thorough research to insure the highhighest
est degree of scientific accuracy for their
work, laboring in laboratory and classclassroom
room with generations of students; and
and maintaining the Herbarium which is
today one of Willamette's most treasured
After the death of Dr. Peck, it was
Mrs. Peck who continued the still enorenormous
mous task of preparing the manuscript
for publication, checking for errors, and
edged the services of members of the
staff of Oregon State University, who
sponsored publication of the manual. In
made by Dr. Helen M. Gilkey, Miss LaRea
J. Dennis, W.U. '57, and Dr. Roy A.
Now that the new edition of the
"Manual of the Higher Plants of Oregon"
is off the press, Mrs. Peck continues to
work in the Herbarium, which is housed
in Collins Hall. The present generation of
college students may see her about the
campus, never guessing what years of
assistance she has given to her husband
and their work, to the students, to the
University, and to the advancement of
science in the State of Oregon.
At their class luncheon, the members
of the Class of 1921 were happy to
salute Mrs. Peck who has long been
considered, informally at least, an honhonorary
orary member of the class, and to pay a
generous tribute of affection to one of

President G. Herbert Smith presents to Dr. John C. Brougher, '23, a citation honoring
the Class of 1923. it reads: A Citation is hereby awarded the Willamette -University Class of
1923 in recognition of its contribution to the ranks of the Nation's leadership, as represented
by this institution's graduating class with most names in Who's Who in America. On behalf
